comments.commentBody: Note that the right wing, including Republican dominated state houses and legislatures, is passing legislation to make it extremely difficult for many of their citizens to vote.  The playing field is tilted against older people, people of color, poorer people, and students.  Unless there are effective lawsuits by the Federal Government and by civil society interests (e.g., League of Women Voters) to prevent these laws from being applied, the game has already been won by the far right.

It is our democratically elected leaders that have brought us to these times and therefore I am not confident they can, or will save us. But what is really fearsome, is  that the people who are actually calling the shots are not our elected leaders at all, but rather those who have taken control of the country with the power of their wealth.

Perhaps Krugman is right that European politicians are making really stupid decisions.

But perhaps the pie is remaining the same size, but the pieces are getting smaller, and no policies, even those of Keynes would make things much better.

Exponential growth at a given constant positive rate cannot continue forever. Yet economists seem to believe in the elixir of continual economic growth.

Krugman suggests that aggregate demand is too low. But until 2008. Americans kept aggregate demand high by simply borrowing more and more against their homes. It seems obvious in retrospect that this could not continue forever. But without the borrowing, why believe that aggregate demand can be maintained?

Krugman suggests that higher inflation targets would help both the US and Europe. But inflation of only 2.7% means that the real yield on 10-year treasuries is negative. Many who are retired count on treasuries as their retirement savings, and the Fed's low interest policy slowly taxes this away, an inflation tax that would be quite rapid if higher inflation targets were adopted.

Krugman suggests that Germany is guilty for having loaned money that inflated the Spain housing bubble. But those who took out the impossible loans were adults. How far do we go in canceling their bad decisions? Even in the US we haven't rescued many of the underwater homeowners.

Perhaps austerity is merely the recognition that there are hard times ahead because growth is no longer possible.

"You should remember that Plato, like Mr. Krugman and so many on the Left today, was a staunch advocate of the totalitarian state and the suppression of much of what we know today as 'individuality."

As someone who has been on the Left my entire 60 years, this totally cracks me up. To me, the last thing that comes to mind as a Liberal is being an advocate of the totalitarian state -- that's absurd. Being on the Left is all about individual freedom, and the freedom to be whoever you want to be.

According to Plato, the soul has "universal" knowledge that is forgotten when, at birth, the soul is imprisoned in the physical body. Perhaps you are atypically more imprisoned? Or maybe you are confusing Plato, an authentic philosopher of major import, with the fiction writer and hypocrite, Ayn Rand?

Have you read Plato's "Republic" and Plato's "Laws"? Especially in the "Laws", Plato struggles with the need to preserve city-state integrity, which requires a degree of control over the individual, but to enable individuality, along with the individual taking responsibility to be self-limiting for the good of whole society. "Suppression" of individuality misrepresents Plato.

In no way was Plato an advocate of Totalitarianism in the modern sense of the word. You need to read Platonic Philosophy and understand Plato's idea of metaphysical and physical dualism. This will explain what he means by an individual's devotion of hir life in service to the community, which is governed by elite philosopher-kings. Again, this is quite divergent from "suppression" of "individuality".

If anything [my interpretation], Plato was an advocate of a Social Republic, which, intriguingly, is not so different than what Jesus advocated.

In any case, imo, you thoroughly misrepresent both Plato and Krugman.

Oh please, save this rant for some forum where people don't know economics or political cant. You wouldn't know "totalitarianism" if you were living under it, though from the sound of your Orwellian tirade, it sounds like you just might be amenable to it.

Montreal Moe,

You should remember that Plato, like Mr. Krugman and so many on the Left today, was a staunch advocate of the totalitarian state and the suppression of much of what we know today as 'individuality.' Plato would have also despised trade unions for their threat to the selfless leadership of the Guardians. After all, Plato was a big fan of the Spartan system of government more than a place like democratic Athens.

As to the merits of Mr. Krugman's views on the value of printing money, the fly in his ointment is that domestic economic growth alone cannot create sustained prosperity. American prosperity in the post-WWII era was not primarily the result of high taxes on the rich or of the growth of labor unions. It was because American dominance in exporting resulted in a transfer of wealth into the US that enabled us to regularly increase wages and investments in technology and infrastructure.

The idea that any economy can have sustained growth through deficit spending is as possible as the idea that Mr. Krugman could build a perpetual motion machine. At some point the debt must be reduced, even if only in relative terms to GDP. And that requires new wealth from outside the nation's economy. Even the confiscation of the wealth of everyone with over $5 million in assets, doubtlessly another Krugman dream, would only delay the inevitable.

The problem, Sherry Jones, is that it is through the markets that the people and institutions that actually HAVE the money to lend convey it to governments.  In the past, governments, such as the French monarchy, simply stole it.  Needless to say, that didn't end well for the French monarchy (and for most of the rest of Europe, either!).

The sovereign states could put whatever interest rates they want on their bond issuances. It's just that there is a clearing price below which no one will buy them, which means putting the interest rate lower than the market rate would not really be an effective way to raise funds.
The French monarch borrowed money, too. That is why its support for the American Revolution bankrupted it. If that were stolen money, they would have had no one to repay.

My question always is, why do we let "markets" magically determine the value of sovereign bonds?  When increasing interest rates risks bankrupting entire countries and crashing the Eurozone?  The article on Spain and Italy asks, “Is the euro crisis back with a vengeance, or do investors have a needless case of anxiety?” And later calls the market “schizophrenic.”  Putting our faith in investors and bond markets is like putting our faith in madmen.  Markets are like herds of wild animals and bond values are arbitrary predictions of which way the herds will run when panicked. We, the people and the governments, are like dogs being wagged by our tails, and as long as we believe in the myth that skittish markets in sovereign bond prices reflects actual value of European countries, and we enact policy accordingly, we will always be wagged by our tails. Giving up governance to "technocrats" who maintain bank profits, while people pay for those ill-gotten gains through austerity measures? Tail wagging the dog.

I have serious doubts whether the Internet in it's present form can ever be completely secured. The Internet is based upon cross platform interconnectivity. The problem is that if anybody can get in, sooner or later everybody will and that includes people who shouldn't.

Despite the stories about groups of hackers, the major security problems today come from organized crime and unfriendly intelligence services. These are not kids with bad complexions and big egos, they are advanced level users, many with PhDs. Charlie Black-hat and his no good friends are much more computer savvy than most ordinary users. If you could find a way to block them, it is very likely that you would block many of your legitimate users as well. That would constitute a sort of failure.

Spot on schrodinger!

In the 1920s Germany suffered economic collapse and national humiliation similar to what is happening right now in Southern Europe. The country was forced to make large payments to other parts of Europe. Those conditions gave rise to the Nazi party, which eventually overthrew German democracy and lead an economic recovery before leading Germany into war.

The conditions for a return of Fascism and a collapse of democracy in southern Europe haven't been this good since the 1930s. Southern Europe had Franco and Mussolini last time around. 2012 is not 1932, but a rebirth of European nationalism and a break up of European institutions like NATO and the EU is a possibility that our State Department should be considering.

In the 1930s, communism offered a realistic alternative to capitalism. Today, capitalism, democracy and globalization have no real intellectual competitor. However, the failure of the current system to bring prosperity to southern Europe creates a gap in the market for promoters of alternative ideologies.

I think community colleges are a good method to graduate individuals with less resources. However, I worry that those who took the very difficult prerequisite courses at a top academic university will receive the short end of the stick when their coursework is compared to those who went to jucos.

Many young people think they can breeze into ICE or an equivalent without years of hard study in the high school years and as freshmen. Alas, life does not work that way.
If you go to the UC Berkeley web site you will see that graduation rates for both 4 year students and transfers is essentially equal, both being in the high 90%.

The academic standards and what is expected at a Junior College are very different from a top academic University.  There are a number of students in the Illinois area who excel in science courses. They may have close to a A average. They apply to the University of Illinois College of Engineering which has an excellent reputation. It is a tough place and there is no grade inflation over there. Unfortunately these students flunk out within a year. Sad but true.

It's gone because it is so much easier to find nearly any book, whether in print or out of print for 50 years, on Amazon.

Now in my 60s, I loved going to book stores from high school through middle age. In the late 1990s I had been looking for a major history book published in the late 19th century - could not get a copy through a number of used bookstores. I went on Amazon and found it. I've seldom been to a book store since.

Beyond having essentially every book in print, you can find the obscure offerings of thousands of used bookstores around the world on Amazon. I've probably bought 50 out of print books on Amazon over the last dozen years - mostly obscure scholarly works. Have found everything I've looked for, although a few were at a pretty steep price.

The Amazon model has revolutionized the way we access the printed word. The farmer in South Dakota now has far better access than anyone had in New York City 20 years ago.

I have some nostalgia for the bookstores - I imagine car drivers in the 1910s were also nostalgic - for blacksmiths. We both got over it.

This is an odd comment.  Mr. Underwood thinks that the hard sciences are amenable to experimentation.  Surely this is true only some of the time, and much of astrophysics is not, although it is open to observation in a systematic way, but, then, so is economics.  And other, possibly less "hard" sciences are open to experimentation, including, e.g., experimental psychology with its manipulation of independent variables and laboratory controls.  Further, Mr. Underwood refers to China as a communist system with some elements of capitalism, although it's hard to find much that is communist there.  Authoritarian, certainly, but not communist except in the name of its single political party.  Odd comment in fundamental ways.
